Description: Fragment of terracotta figurine of Isis-Hathor. Her hair is parted in the middle and Isis-locks fall onto her shoulders; she wears an enormous tripple wreath bound across the front with a narrow horizontal garland. From the top of the wreath would have risen a kalathos, now lost. Covered in thick white coating, with red paint on lips, eyes and eye-brows painted black. The tripple wreath encircles her face with pink, yellow and red bands crossed by horizontal blue band. Brown, muddy clay. Mould-made and hollow. Red-brown micacous Nile silt. The face is broken just below chin, the left side and back are also missing.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallel from early 1st century BC context in Tell Atrib (Szymańska 2005, no. 34; see also late 3rd to 2nd century BC parallels nos. 26 and 28). Very close parallel, also from Naukratis (Bailey 2008, no.2997, GR1888,0601.110 ). Szymańska, H. 2005, Terres cuites d’Athribis, Turnhout.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.166) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4542 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
